publication.title: L'usage des cartes dans l'Itala Illustrata de de Biondo Flavio
publication.subtitle: L'usage des cartes
publication.abstract: Biondo Flavio's Italia Illustrata is a remarkable work from the 15th century that exemplifies the geographical culture of humanism. Commissioned by Alphonse of Aragon, it aims to catalog illustrious figures in Italy but goes beyond by meticulously describing the Italian landscape and celebrating its connection to ancient Rome. This article examines three aspects of : the text's composition, the types of maps mentioned, and their significance in Biondo's work. By analyzing his sources and methods, we gain insights into the humanist's approach to portraying Italy's past and present.
publication.copyrightHolder: Bibliotheca Hertziana - Max Planck Institute for Art History

author.affiliation: D'epartement d'histoire et d'arch'eologie, Universit'e de Tours
